text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

Rearranged existing IRM content to place internal control information under IRM 4.51.8.1 to conform to the new rules described in IRM 1.11.2.2.5, Address Management and Internal Controls. Added new subsections for Program Scope, Background and Authority, Program Controls, Acronyms and Related Resources. Subsequent subsections were renumbered.

EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS IRM 4.51.8 dated September 25, 2015 is superseded.

) Purpose: The Compliance Assurance Process (CAP) is a method of and resolving tax issues through open, cooperative and transparent between the IRS and LB&I taxpayers prior to the ﬁling of a return. Through CAP (or “the Program”), the taxpayer should achieve tax certainty sooner with less administrative burden than conventional examinations. The seeks to identify, develop and resolve the material issues before the return ﬁled. It relies on the transparent and cooperative interaction of the parties the contemporaneous exchange of information. The Program does not taxpayers with guidance on, or resolution of, prospective or incomplete actions outside of existing procedures. (
) Audience: The primary users are LB&I employees. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Eastern Compliance Practice Area, LB&I Division. (
) Program Owner: The Eastern Compliance Practice Area is responsible for administration, procedures and updates related to the program. (
) Primary Stakeholders: The primary stakeholders are LB&I employees and taxpayers who participate in the program. (
) On December

, the IRS announced that it was initiating the CAP for large business taxpayers. The objective of this pilot was “to reduce taxpayer burden and uncertainty while assuring the Service of the accuracy tax returns prior to ﬁling, thereby reducing or eliminating the need for examinations.” See Announcement
IRB

, the IRS announced that the six-year old CAP Pilot for large business taxpayers was being made permanent and expanded to the Compliance Maintenance phase. See News Release IR

, the IRS announced that it was considering changes to CAP Program and that no new taxpayers would be accepted for the
plication period. See News Release IR

Increase transparency and cooperation between the IRS and and c. Reduce burden of tax administration and compliance. Internal Revenue Manual
Compliance Assurance Process (CAP) Examinations 4.51.8 page

Purpose: The Compliance Assurance Process (CAP) is a method of and resolving tax issues through open, cooperative and transparent interaction between the IRS and LB&I taxpayers prior to the ﬁling of a return. Through CAP (or “the Program”), the taxpayer should achieve tax certainty sooner and with less administrative burden than conventional examinations. The Program seeks to identify, develop and resolve the material issues before the return is ﬁled. It relies on the transparent and cooperative interaction of the parties and the contemporaneous exchange of information. The Program does not provide taxpayers with guidance on, or resolution of, prospective or incomplete trans- actions outside of existing procedures.
4.51.8.1.1 (04-16-2020) Background and Authority
Improve tax compliance by enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of the issue identiﬁcation, development, and resolution processes and pro
cedures; Increase transparency and cooperation between the IRS and taxpayers; and Reduce burden of tax administration and compliance.
) See https://www.irs.gov/businesses/corporations/compliance-assurance- process for application forms, FAQs and additional information. Resources (
) The Program consists of three phases: CAP, Compliance Maintenance and Bridge. Three Phases of the (

) In the CAP phase, a taxpayer is expected to make open, comprehensive and contemporaneous disclosures of its material issues in writing. The taxpayer is also expected to provide a full description of its material issues to include the relevant facts and circumstances and the proposed tax positions. If, after the receipt and review of the Post-Filing Representation, the IRS determines that all material issues have been disclosed and resolved the taxpayer will receive a Full Acceptance Letter. This letter constitutes written conﬁrmation that, subject to the completion of the post-ﬁling review of the return, the IRS will accept the return as ﬁled. Any material issues that were not disclosed or resolved and any resolved issues that were not reported as agreed before return is ﬁled may be resolved through the post-ﬁling examination process. (

) A taxpayer with a limited number of material issues, that continues to satisfy the CAP eligibility and suitability requirements, and has completed at least complete CAP phase, may progress, if approved, to the Compliance Mainte- nance phase. In the Compliance Maintenance phase, the IRS reduces the level of review based on the complexity and number of issues, and the er’s history of cooperation and transparency in the CAP. As with the CAP phase, a taxpayer is expected to make open, comprehensive, and contempo-
See https://www.irs.gov/businesses/corporations/compliance-assurance- process for application forms, FAQs and additional information.

Process (CAP) Examinations

raneous disclosures of its material issues in writing. If, after the receipt and review of the Post-Filing Representation, the IRS determines that all issues have been disclosed and resolved the taxpayer will receive a Full ceptance Letter. Any material issues that were not disclosed or resolved any resolved issues that were not reported as agreed before the return is may be resolved through the post-ﬁling examination process. (

) A taxpayer with few, if any, material issues, that continues to satisfy the eligibility and suitability requirements, and has completed at least one Compliance Maintenance phase (or at least one complete CAP phase the best interest of sound tax administration), may progress, if approved, to Bridge phase. In the Bridge phase, the IRS will not accept any disclosures, conduct any reviews or provide any assurances regarding the bridged the taxpayer has a speciﬁc issue on the bridged return that it wants the consider, the taxpayer may submit a request for a pre-ﬁling agreement provided that the issue meets the requirements for a pre-ﬁling agreement. (

) A taxpayer may withdraw from any phase of the CAP by submitting a request. Additionally, the IRS may terminate a taxpayer’s participation in phase when the taxpayer fails to adhere to the terms of the CAP of Understanding (MOU). (

) The CAP phase employs real-time issue resolution to improve tax The IRS and taxpayer work together to achieve this goal by identifying, oping and resolving the material issues prior to the ﬁling of the return. A successful conclusion of the CAP allows the IRS to achieve an acceptable level of assurance regarding the accuracy of the taxpayer’s ﬁled return and substantially shorten the length of any post-ﬁling review or examination. (
) To be eligible for participation in the CAP program, a taxpayer must meet following criteria: a. Have assets of $
million or more; b. Be a U.S. publicly-traded corporation with a legal requirement to and submit Forms
-Q and
-K to the Securities & Exchange Commission, or an entity that was accepted into the

CAP and agree to provide the IRS with unaudited quarterly ﬁnancial state- ments and audited annual ﬁnancial statements for the entity that was accepted into the Program. (These ﬁnancial statements must be prepared in accordance with United States Generally Accepted ing Principles.) c. Not be under investigation by, or in litigation with, the IRS or other ernment agency that would limit the IRS’ access to current corporate records; and d. If currently under examination, must not have more than one open return and one open unﬁled return on the ﬁrst day of the applicant’s year. (
) A return is treated as closed for purposes of the open return criterion if it been ‘closed in examination’ with Status Code
or qualiﬁes for one or of the following exceptions: a. Previously Closed Exception: Any previously closed return with Status Code
that has been reopened to process a claim or other Internal Revenue Manual

raneous disclosures of its material issues in writing. If, after the receipt and review of the Post-Filing Representation, the IRS determines that all material issues have been disclosed and resolved the taxpayer will receive a Full Ac- ceptance Letter. Any material issues that were not disclosed or resolved and any resolved issues that were not reported as agreed before the return is ﬁled may be resolved through the post-ﬁling examination process. (

) A taxpayer with few, if any, material issues, that continues to satisfy the CAP eligibility and suitability requirements, and has completed at least one complete Compliance Maintenance phase (or at least one complete CAP phase when in the best interest of sound tax administration), may progress, if approved, to the Bridge phase. In the Bridge phase, the IRS will not accept any disclosures, conduct any reviews or provide any assurances regarding the bridged return. If the taxpayer has a speciﬁc issue on the bridged return that it wants the IRS to consider, the taxpayer may submit a request for a pre-ﬁling agreement provided that the issue meets the requirements for a pre-ﬁling agreement. (

) A taxpayer may withdraw from any phase of the CAP by submitting a written request. Additionally, the IRS may terminate a taxpayer’s participation in any phase when the taxpayer fails to adhere to the terms of the CAP Memorandum of Understanding (MOU). (

) The CAP phase employs real-time issue resolution to improve tax compliance. The IRS and taxpayer work together to achieve this goal by identifying, devel- oping and resolving the material issues prior to the ﬁling of the return. A successful conclusion of the CAP allows the IRS to achieve an acceptable level of assurance regarding the accuracy of the taxpayer’s ﬁled return and to substantially shorten the length of any post-ﬁling review or examination.

Any material issues that were not disclosed or resolved and any resolved issues that were not reported as agreed before the return is ﬁled may be resolved through the post-ﬁling examination process.

) For a new applicant currently under examination to be eligible for in the CAP Program, the current cycle must be closed and the subsequent cycle not started on the ﬁrst day of the applicant’s CAP year. (

) For all new taxpayers, any unexamined return with an open statute will be assessed as part of the required compliance check for the ﬁrst CAP year. If examination team determines that a material issue should be examined, the return with that issue may be placed under examination. Any unexamined returns that are placed under examination will be treated as ‘one ﬁled’ return for purposes of the return criterion. These returns must be closed by the end of the second CAP year or the taxpayer may not be eligible to participate in the third CAP year. (
) Since the CAP Program is based on the transparent and cooperative tion between the taxpayer and the IRS, a taxpayer that does not exhibit this type of behavior is not suitable for the Program. (

) Examples of signiﬁcant or material failures to exhibit transparent and tive behavior include, but are not limited to: a. Not adhering to IDR response times or providing incomplete IDR responses. b. Not engaging in meaningful or good faith issue resolution discussions. c. Failing to thoroughly disclose a material issue in a timely manner. d. Failing to disclose a tax shelter or listed transaction. e. Failing to disclose an investigation or litigation that limits IRS access to current corporate records. f. Frequently ﬁling claims or requesting appeals, and g. Not adhering to the terms of the CAP MOU. (

) A taxpayer interested in participating in the CAP Program that meets the bility and suitability criteria must complete the CAP application form and any related documents for acceptance into the Program. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

Assurance Process (CAP) Examinations 4.51.8 page
) The application must be submitted annually during the application period mediately preceding the CAP year. The application period is generally from September
st to October
st but may be subject to change on a basis. The application period for each year will be announced in advance the application period opening. (

) The application is available on IRS.gov and should be submitted by one of following methods: a. If a taxpayer is a returning CAP applicant, submit the application to account coordinator (AC) or case manager. b. If the taxpayer is a new CAP applicant, email the application to cap.program@irs.gov. Enter “CAP Application” and the tax year in subject line. (

) The CAP team members assigned to the taxpayer will evaluate the to determine if the taxpayer meets the eligibility and suitability criteria and forward a recommendation to the LB&I Geographic Compliance Practice director with jurisdiction over the taxpayer. (

) In evaluating an application, the IRS will consider factors such as: a. Number of open examinations b. Number and complexity of issues worked in prior examinations c. Level of cooperation and transparency in prior examinations d. Adherence to the terms of the CAP MOU in prior CAP years e. Effectiveness of internal controls f. Occurrence of an ownership change or a ﬁnancial restatement g. Availability of IRS and taxpayer resources (

) If a taxpayer’s application is approved by the IRS, the taxpayer will be in writing, by the territory manager assigned to the taxpayer, that it was accepted into the CAP Program and selected for one of the three phases the Program. (

) After receiving the Notiﬁcation of Acceptance Letter, the taxpayer must a standardized CAP MOU that outlines the CAP requirements and the agreement to meet the requirements. The MOU must be executed by taxpayer and returned to the AC by the requested date to secure its tion in the CAP Program. Once the MOU is executed by the IRS and the taxpayer will be accepted into the CAP Program. Note: The CAP MOU is applicable to a single tax year, known as the CAP new MOU is executed for each CAP year. To continue in the CAP a taxpayer must reapply, be accepted and execute a new MOU for the year.

After receiving the Notiﬁcation of Acceptance Letter, the taxpayer must a standardized CAP MOU that outlines the CAP requirements and establishes the agreement to meet the requirements. The MOU must be executed by the taxpayer and returned to the AC by the requested date to secure its participa- tion in the CAP Program. Once the MOU is executed by the IRS and the taxpayer will be accepted into the CAP Program.

) The IRS, in its sole discretion, may decline to approve a taxpayer’s application whenever warranted by the facts and circumstances of the application or in the interest of sound tax administration. If a taxpayer’s application is not approved by the IRS, the taxpayer will be informed, in writing, by the territory manager assigned to the taxpayer, that it was not accepted into the CAP Program and the reason or reasons why it was not accepted into the Program.
Adherence to the processes and procedures established by the CAP MOU is an integral part of identifying, developing and resolving issues, and assuring
the IRS of the accuracy of the return. Failure to comply with the terms of the MOU will result in removal of the taxpayer from the CAP Program. (

) Once a taxpayer is accepted into the CAP Program, the IRS will assign an AC to the taxpayer. The AC serves as the primary IRS representative, facilitates tax compliance and provides a single point of contact for all federal tax matters. (

) The IRS will also provide a list of additional IRS participants on the CAP team to the taxpayer. The IRS team members will include, but may not be limited the team manager, the territory manager and the director of ﬁeld operations (DFO). Similarly, the taxpayer must provide a list of designated personnel to act as points of contact for gathering information, answering questions and resolving issues. (
) The taxpayer is expected to make open, comprehensive and disclosures of the material issues. (

) A material issue is deﬁned as any recurring or repeating issue that has a change exceeding the materiality threshold, or any new issue that exceeds materiality threshold, or any other issue that is required to be reserved or reported on Schedule UTP. An issue is deﬁned as a completed business action, an item, a change in accounting method or any other issue with material tax impact. (

) To be considered comprehensive, the material issue must be disclosed in writing and the full disclosure must include the historic facts, surrounding cir- cumstances and proposed tax position to include the law relied upon to develop the position. (
) To be considered contemporaneous, the material issue must be disclosed within
days of the transaction being completed or the non-transaction issue having an impact on the taxpayer’s federal income tax liability. (
) To allow sufficient time for issue resolution in pre-ﬁling, the latest date for the taxpayer to submit disclosures is
days after the end of the tax year. Disclo- sures received after this date will be accepted but may not be reviewed in ﬁling. (

) The AC will maintain an issues list which contains the material issues disclosed by the taxpayer or identiﬁed by the IRS that will be reviewed by the IRS. Any disputes regarding which material issues will be included on the issues list will be elevated to the territory manager. However, the ultimate decision regarding which material issues will be reviewed remains within the discretion of the IRS. (

) The taxpayer will submit an initial issues list with the CAP application. By the date of the opening conference, the parties will jointly determine which issues will be included on the initial issue list. Additional material issues may be added to the issues list during the CAP year by taxpayer disclosure or IRS identiﬁcation, but may only be added with the approval of the territory manager. (
) If issues are added to the issues list without consultation with the taxpayer, taxpayer should elevate this situation to the DFO. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
U

If issues are added to the issues list without consultation with the taxpayer, the taxpayer should elevate this situation to the DFO.

) The parties will jointly determine the scope of the CAP review by setting riality thresholds that are used as a guide by the parties to determine issues should be disclosed and reviewed. The parties will openly discuss tions where exceptions to the materiality thresholds may be warranted. However, the ultimate decision of identifying issues remains within the tion of the IRS. (

) Materiality thresholds are used in the CAP for the taxpayer to know which issues should be disclosed. They are not relevant to the adjustments that be made regarding the tax consequences of such issues. Therefore, ments to issues may be made that are below the relevant materiality thresholds. (

) Further, materiality thresholds may be reconsidered during the CAP year. thresholds will be documented in the CAP Plan and apply only to the CAP year. The CAP Plan will be discussed during the opening conference a copy provided to the taxpayer at this time or shortly thereafter. (

) Notwithstanding the materiality thresholds and issue identiﬁcation process discussed above, the IRS may consider the following items for compliance review regardless of when or how they are identiﬁed: a. Tax shelters b. Listed transactions c. Transactions of interest d. Fraudulent items e. LB&I compliance initiatives f. LB&I directives g. Emerging issues (
) In addition, obvious computational/mathematical or accounting that are not technical or legal in nature may be corrected. (

) Taxpayers will provide information and documentation proactively and as requested by the AC and other team members. The team will promptly all relevant information provided and will communicate to the taxpayer a. Additional information is required. b. The IRS disagrees with the taxpayer’s proposed tax treatment. c. The proposed tax treatment is appropriate. (

) Taxpayers will provide the IRS with: a. Industry overviews b. Current legal, accounting and tax organizational charts reﬂecting all related entities and the ﬂow of relevant information involving those entities c. Financial performance information d. Information on any anticipated signiﬁcant events that will affect the reporting for the tax year e. Necessary resources for disclosure of requested information (

) Taxpayers will provide the AC with tax schedules and computations for all rollover and recurring adjustments from any previously examined and period that impact the CAP year, including the impact of any closing ments or Appeals settlements. The taxpayer will provide these initial

Taxpayers will provide the AC with tax schedules and computations for all rollover and recurring adjustments from any previously examined and closed period that impact the CAP year, including the impact of any closing agree- ments or Appeals settlements. The taxpayer will provide these initial
disclosures by the date of the opening conference. The parties will discuss effect of such adjustments on the CAP year and any unexamined year and corporate any changes as appropriate. (
) The taxpayer will provide notice and documentation of any subsequent issue resolutions from a prior examination within
business days of the The parties will discuss the effect of such resolutions on the CAP year and unexamined year and incorporate any changes as appropriate. (

) The taxpayer will immediately notify the AC of any investigation initiated on taxpayer by a federal or state agency. The notiﬁcation should include: a. A detailed explanation of the investigation b. An evaluation of whether access to corporate books and records could be limited c. Any material issues that could result from the investigation (

) The taxpayer will notify the AC of any foreign initiated examinations or ments that may impact income, expenses or credits reported in the United States, for the current or prior tax years, and will update this information on quarterly basis as the information becomes available. (
) All information provided to the IRS in connection with the CAP is return infor- mation protected from disclosure by the conﬁdentially provisions of IRC (

) Ordinarily, a formal Information Document Request (IDR) should not be necessary in CAP and informal requests should be sufficient. However, if it is necessary to issue an IDR, the scope of the IDR should be discussed and parties should reach a mutually agreed upon due date for the response. (
) The requirements for issuing IDRs, outlined in IRM Exhibit
, apply to both the pre-ﬁling and post-ﬁling phases of CAP. However, the IDR enforce- ment process outlined in IRM Exhibit
, applies only to ﬁled returns a delinquency notice and subsequent summons may only be issued during post-ﬁling phase of CAP. (

) The IRS will promptly evaluate the IDR response for completeness and, after thorough analysis of the response, will discuss the results of the review with the taxpayer. The parties must strive for urgency during this real-time compli- ance review process in order to meet the CAP Program goals. (

) The IRS and taxpayers should interact on a regular basis. Calls and should be held as needed to discuss and provide relevant information and documentation, and to discuss the status of the CAP and resolve concerns they arise during the CAP. The parties should have in attendance tives with sufficient authority to resolve any concerns being addressed. (

) Since the CAP Program relies on the transparent and cooperative interaction of the parties, the IRS and taxpayer should meet as needed to evaluate and document the transparency and cooperation of the parties. (

) The IRS and taxpayer should regularly engage in discussions for resolving factual or technical differences related to the identiﬁed material issues. After the parties have resolved an issue other than through simple factual tion, the IRS may draft an Issue Resolution Agreement (IRA) for that issue.
The taxpayer will immediately notify the AC of any investigation initiated on taxpayer by a federal or state agency. The notiﬁcation should include:
All information provided to the IRS in connection with the CAP is return infor- mation protected from disclosure by the conﬁdentially provisions of IRC 6103.

The IRS will promptly evaluate the IDR response for completeness and, after a thorough analysis of the response, will discuss the results of the review with the taxpayer. The parties must strive for urgency during this real-time compli- ance review process in order to meet the CAP Program goals.
Assurance Process (CAP) Examinations 4.51.8 page
Process (CAP) Examinations

) Upon the issuance of an IRA, the parties will mutually agree to a timely response date. In the response, the taxpayer will indicate its agreement or agreement with the IRA. If the taxpayer disagrees with the IRA, the will state, in writing, the relevant facts and legal arguments for its position. (

) If for any reason the taxpayer is unable to comply with the due date of an response, the taxpayer will notify the IRS immediately, explain the circum- stances for the delay, and the parties will agree to a revised due date. (

) Ordinarily an IRA is sufficient for documenting the resolution of most issues. However, as deemed appropriate, the IRS may prepare a Form Closing Agreement, based on the completed IRA. Issues resolved using closing agreements may be, but are not limited to, very large or issues that may materially affect subsequent years. (

) Issues that are resolved through requests for simple factual clariﬁcation or merely require a taxpayer to expand or elaborate on information that was viously provided by the taxpayer do not generally require an IRA or a agreement. IRAs are only required to be drafted for issues where the IRS not agree with the taxpayer’s position or when a closing agreement is necessary. The issuance of an IRA when the IRS agrees with the position is optional. (
) Once both parties agree that an issue has been fully disclosed, the IRS will ordinarily have

days to resolve the issue. If additional time is required, Case Territory Manager in collaboration with the Issue Territory Manager approve the additional time. The IRS will promptly inform the taxpayer of approved time extensions. (
) If the issue is eligible for the Fast Track Settlement (FTS) process and still resolved after

days or a different period if an extension is approved, the IRS will initiate the FTS process and the taxpayer must agree to participate the process. If the issue is still unresolved after the FTS process, the retains its traditional appeal rights. (
) Within

days of the date the return is ﬁled, the taxpayer will provide the a Post-Filing Representation executed by an officer of the taxpayer with authority to sign the return. The Post-Filing Representation is a pro-forma document attached to the CAP MOU that includes: a. A statement that all material issues were disclosed and resolved as of the date that the return was ﬁled or a full description of the material issues that were not disclosed or resolved as of that date; b. A statement that all resolved issues were reported as agreed as of the date that the return was ﬁled or a full description of the resolved that were not reported as agreed as of that date; and c. A declaration that “Under penalties of perjury, I declare that I have examined this letter and accompanying documents, if any, and that, to the best of my knowledge and belief, this letter contains all relevant mation, and that the representations in this letter are true, correct, and complete”

A statement that all material issues were disclosed and resolved as of the date that the return was ﬁled or a full description of the material issues that were not disclosed or resolved as of that date; A statement that all resolved issues were reported as agreed as of the date that the return was ﬁled or a full description of the resolved issues that were not reported as agreed as of that date; and A declaration that “Under penalties of perjury, I declare that I have examined this letter and accompanying documents, if any, and that, to the best of my knowledge and belief, this letter contains all relevant mation, and that the representations in this letter are true, correct, and complete”

) If, after the receipt and review of the Post-Filing Representation, the IRS mines that all material issues have been disclosed and resolved through and simple factual clariﬁcation, issue resolution agreement or closing the IRS will provide the taxpayer with a Full Acceptance Letter. (

) The Full Acceptance Letter constitutes written conﬁrmation that, subject to completion of the post-ﬁling review of the return, the IRS will accept the tax- payer’s return if it is ﬁled consistent with the resolutions of the resolved and no additional material issues or correlative adjustments are discovered during the post-ﬁling review that were not previously disclosed. (

) If, after the receipt and review of the Post-Filing Representation, the IRS mines that the taxpayer did not disclose all material issues or that the IRS the taxpayer did not resolve all identiﬁed material issues, the IRS will the taxpayer with a Partial Acceptance Letter. (

) The Partial Acceptance Letter constitutes written conﬁrmation that, subject the completion of the post-ﬁling review of the return, the IRS will accept the taxpayer’s return, but for the undisclosed and unresolved material issues correlative adjustments, if the return is ﬁled consistent with the resolutions the resolved issues and no additional material issues and correlative adjust- ments are discovered during the post-ﬁling review that were not previously disclosed. (
) After a taxpayer ﬁles its return, the AC will secure a copy of the return and initiate the post-ﬁling review. The goal for completing this review when a Acceptance Letter has been issued is within
days of the ﬁling of the (

page (

) The taxpayer will disclose its research credit activities by preparing and mitting the CAP Research Credit Questionnaire (CRCQ) in accordance with the form instructions and other guidance posted to the CAP page on (
) The AC will review the completed CRCQ and prepare the Account Evaluation of the CAP Research Credit Questionnaire. (
) The Research Risk Review Team (RT) will review the completed CRCQ and assess the taxpayer’s research credit risk. (
) The RT will communicate the results of its risk assessment to the AC during the planning phase of the pre-ﬁling review. (
) If consensus is not reached between the RT and CAP teams regarding the scope of the research credit review, the matter will be elevated to the next level of management. (
) The taxpayer will make open, comprehensive and contemporaneous disclo- sures of its material transfer pricing transactions. (

) The taxpayer will disclose its material transfer pricing transactions by the Material Intercompany Transactions Template (MITT) in accordance with the form instructions and other guidance posted to the CAP page on (
) The Transfer Pricing Risk Assessment (TPRA) Team will review the MITT and assess the taxpayer’s transfer pricing risk. (
) The TPRA Team will communicate the results of its risk assessment to the during the planning phase of the pre-ﬁling review. (
) If consensus is not reached between the CAP and TPRA teams regarding scope and depth of the transfer pricing transaction review, the matter will be elevated to the next level of management. (
) A taxpayer that has already submitted a request for, or renewal of, an Pricing Agreement (APA) under Rev. Proc.
(or successor thereto) and/or a request for assistance from the U.S. Competent Authority under Proc.

(or successor thereto) will notify the AC of the existence of requests and provide a copy of the request or renewal. The AC will then contact the appropriate Advance Pricing and Mutual Agreement (APMA) or the Treaty Assistance and Interpretation Team (TAIT) lead or analyst to ensure ongoing coordination between the CAP and APMA/TAIT programs. (

) The taxpayer is encouraged, and may be required, to seek an APA to cover recurring controlled transaction. A taxpayer with ongoing transfer pricing may contact, or may be contacted by, the AC to request a meeting with to discuss the beneﬁts and/or requirement of entering into an APA. The taxpayer will provide notice and documentation of any subsequent of items or issues in prior examination cycles within
business days of the agreed determinations. The parties will discuss the effect of such on any unexamined tax years and on the CAP year and incorporate the changes as appropriate. (
) The taxpayer will notify the AC of any foreign initiated examinations, adjustments or assessments that may impact income, expenses and/or

LB&I Case reported in the United States, for the CAP year or any prior tax years, and update such information on an as-needed basis to report any changes as information becomes available. (

) A taxpayer with a limited number of material issues that continues to satisfy the CAP eligibility and suitability requirement, and has completed at least complete CAP phase, may progress, if approved, to the Compliance Mainte- nance phase. (

) In the Compliance Maintenance phase, the IRS, at its discretion, will the level of review based on the complexity and volume of issues, and the payer’s history of compliance, cooperation and transparency in the CAP. (
) The taxpayer continues to make open, comprehensive and disclosures of its material issues. (

) In evaluating a taxpayer’s eligibility for the Compliance Maintenance phase, the IRS will consider the following factors: a. The taxpayer continues to satisfy the eligibility and suitability criteria. b. The taxpayer has completed at least one full CAP phase. c. The taxpayer has effective internal controls. d. Historically, the taxpayer has a limited number of issues that are resolved before the tax return has been ﬁled, and has been compliant, cooperative and transparent in the prior phases. Note: The remaining processes and procedures for the Compliance phase are fundamentally the same as for the CAP phase. Therefore, to duplication, they have not been listed here. Refer to IRM
for information. (

) A taxpayer with few, if any, material issues that continues to satisfy the CAP eligibility and suitability requirements, and has completed at least one ance Maintenance phase (or at least one complete CAP phase when in the best interest of sound tax administration), may progress, if approved, to the Bridge phase. (
) In the Bridge phase, the IRS will not accept any disclosures, conduct any reviews or provide any assurances regarding the bridged return. (
) A taxpayer in the Bridge phase is still considered to be a participant in the CAP Program and will be treated as a returning CAP taxpayer in the subse- quent year CAP application process. (
) However, if the taxpayer has a speciﬁc issue on the bridged return that it wants the IRS to consider, the taxpayer may submit a request for a pre-ﬁling agreement (see Rev. Proc.
or its successor) provided that the issue meets the requirements for a pre-ﬁling agreement. (

) In evaluating a taxpayer’s eligibility for the Bridge phase, the IRS will the following factors: a. The taxpayer continues to satisfy the eligibility and suitability criteria. b. The taxpayer has completed at least one full CAP phase. c. The taxpayer has effective internal controls. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

d. Historically, the taxpayer has few, if any, material issues that are resolved before the tax return has been ﬁled, and has been compliant, cooperative and transparent in the prior phases. Note: Selection for this phase is recognition that the compliance risk for the er’s return is very low and that the expenditure of resources by the IRS taxpayer to examine this return is not in the best interest of tax administra- tion. ) If the taxpayer or the IRS is unable or has failed to comply with the terms of the CAP MOU, the parties will attempt to resolve these concerns on a poraneous basis. The parties will meet to discuss, and the concerns and resolution efforts will be documented using the Evaluation of Cooperation Transparency Form. (

) If the concerns are not resolved and the IRS determines that the taxpayer failed to adhere to the terms of the MOU, the territory manager assigned to case will issue the taxpayer a written notice that informs the taxpayer of the IRS’ concerns. (
) If the concerns are not resolved within

days of receiving such notiﬁcation, the DFO assigned to the case will issue the taxpayer a Termination Letter its participation in the CAP Program will cease. The IRS may then conduct a post-ﬁling examination of the taxpayer’s open ﬁled return. (

) Examples of signiﬁcant or consistent failures to adhere to the terms of the Program that may result in the issuance of a Termination Letter include: a. Not adhering to IDR response times or providing incomplete IDR responses b. Not engaging in meaningful or good faith issue resolution discussions c. Failing to thoroughly disclose a material issue in a timely manner d. Failing to disclose a tax shelter or listed transaction e. Failing to disclose an investigation or litigation that limits IRS access to current corporate records f. Frequently ﬁling claims or requesting appeals g. Not adhering to the terms of the CAP MOU (

) If at any time the taxpayer determines that it no longer wants to participate the CAP Program, the taxpayer may provide the IRS a written request to withdraw from the program. Upon receipt of such request, the IRS will issue the taxpayer a Termination Letter that terminates its participation in the CAP program. The IRS may then conduct a post-ﬁling examination of the open ﬁled return. (
) All potential claims for credit or refund must be brought to the attention of AC as soon as the taxpayer becomes aware that it has potential claims. (
) All claims or requests for tentative refunds affecting federal income tax must be ﬁled using Form
X or Form

, which states that if a taxpayer is required to ﬁle a claim for refund or credit on a particular form, then the together with appropriate supporting evidence, will be ﬁled in a manner tent with such form, form instructions, publications and other guidance found on the IRS.gov website. Examples of signiﬁcant or consistent failures to adhere to the terms of the CAP Program that may result in the issuance of a Termination Letter include:

Not adhering to IDR response times or providing incomplete IDR responses Not engaging in meaningful or good faith issue resolution discussions Failing to thoroughly disclose a material issue in a timely manner Failing to disclose a tax shelter or listed transaction Failing to disclose an investigation or litigation that limits IRS access current corporate records Frequently ﬁling claims or requesting appeals Not adhering to the terms of the CAP MOU
All potential claims for credit or refund must be brought to the attention of the AC as soon as the taxpayer becomes aware that it has potential claims.
All claims or requests for tentative refunds affecting federal income tax liability must be ﬁled using Form
X or Form
The claims must meet the standards of Treas. Reg.

, which states that if a taxpayer is required to ﬁle a claim for refund or credit on a particular form, then the claim, together with appropriate supporting evidence, will be ﬁled in a manner consis- tent with such form, form instructions, publications and other guidance found on the IRS.gov website.

) If it is determined that the ﬁled return will result in a refund claim subject to review by the JCT, any closing agreements cannot be executed on behalf of the government until they have been reviewed and approved by the JCT. closing agreements signed by the taxpayer will be submitted with the Joint Committee report and if the JCT takes no exception to the report and agree- ments, the DFO assigned to the case may sign the agreements. (

) If a Full Acceptance Letter was issued and the post-ﬁling review conﬁrms all material issues were disclosed and resolved, and all resolved issues reported as agreed, the Joint Committee report will be forwarded to the JCT. When the JCT has completed its review and sent the clearance notiﬁcation the IRS, any applicable closing agreements will be executed by the IRS. (

) If a Partial Acceptance Letter was issued, once all the remaining issues been fully resolved, the Joint Committee report will be forwarded to the JCT. When the JCT has completed its review and sent the clearance notiﬁcation the IRS, any applicable closing agreements will be executed by the IRS. (
) As part of the CAP recalibration, signiﬁcant changes were made to the CAP Program starting in the
CAP year. (
) The review for any CAP year should be conducted under the provisions of MOU that was executed for that CAP year. For example, the

MOU that: “Quarterly, the CAP team manager and the taxpayer and/or its tative will assess and document transparency and cooperation. ”Therefore, CAP team manager and the taxpayer should continue to assess and transparency and cooperation on a quarterly basis until the
CAP year completed.

If a Partial Acceptance Letter was issued, once all the remaining issues have been fully resolved, the Joint Committee report will be forwarded to the JCT. When the JCT has completed its review and sent the clearance notiﬁcation to the IRS, any applicable closing agreements will be executed by the IRS.
The review for any CAP year should be conducted under the provisions of the MOU that was executed for that CAP year. For example, the

MOU states that: “Quarterly, the CAP team manager and the taxpayer and/or its represen- tative will assess and document transparency and cooperation. ”Therefore, the CAP team manager and the taxpayer should continue to assess and document transparency and cooperation on a quarterly basis until the
CAP year is completed.
